The temple is closely associated with the Guruvayur Temple, as it is believed that the idol was brought here for safekeeping during Tipu Sultan's invasion. The annual Ambalappuzha Arattu festival is a major attraction, drawing thousands of devotees from across the state.

temples.name: Ananthapura Lake Temple
temples.text: Ananthapura Lake Temple is the only lake temple in Kerala, dedicated to Lord Anantha Padmanabha (Lord Vishnu), located in Kasaragod district.
temples.history: Ananthapura Lake Temple is an ancient Hindu temple believed to be the original seat of Lord Anantha Padmanabha, the deity of the famous Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram. The temple, surrounded by a serene lake, is unique for its location and legends. It is said that the deity manifested here before appearing in Thiruvananthapuram. Another fascinating aspect of the temple is the presence of a vegetarian crocodile named 'Babiya,' believed to be guarding the temple for centuries. The temple's structure, built in a traditional Kerala style, and its scenic surroundings make it a significant pilgrimage and tourist attraction.

temples.name: Aranmula Parthasarathy Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Krishna as Parthasarathy, this temple is an important pilgrimage site in Kerala. Located in Aranmula, it is known for its association with the famous Aranmula Boat Race and its connection to the Pandavas from the Mahabharata.
temples.history: The Aranmula Parthasarathy Temple is one of the 108 Divya Desams dedicated to Lord Vishnu. It is believed that the idol was brought here by the Pandavas during their exile. The temple is also associated with the legend of the Aranmula Vallamkali (boat race), a tradition dating back centuries. The structure follows Kerala's traditional architectural style, and the temple’s murals and carvings depict scenes from Hindu mythology.

temples.name: Arattupuzha Temple
temples.text: Arattupuzha Temple is dedicated to Lord Ayyappa and is famous for the annual Arattupuzha Pooram, a grand festival featuring a spectacular procession of decorated elephants.
temples.history: The Arattupuzha Temple is believed to be over 3,000 years old, making it one of Kerala’s oldest temples. The temple festival, Arattupuzha Pooram, is said to have been initiated by Lord Parasurama, the legendary creator of Kerala. The event attracts thousands of devotees and features a procession of caparisoned elephants, traditional music, and rituals that enhance its spiritual grandeur.

temples.name: Attukal Temple
temples.text: Attukal Bhagavathy Temple is dedicated to Goddess Bhagavathy, considered an incarnation of Parvati. The temple is known for the Attukal Pongala, one of the largest gatherings of women devotees in the world.
temples.history: Attukal Temple is renowned for its Pongala festival, where millions of women gather to offer rice porridge to the goddess. The temple is associated with the Kannaki legend from the Tamil epic Silappathikaram, which narrates the story of a devoted wife who becomes a goddess. The temple’s architecture is a blend of traditional Kerala and Dravidian styles, featuring intricate sculptures and murals.

temples.name: Chakkulathukavu Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Goddess Durga, Chakkulathukavu Temple is known for the annual Pongala festival, where thousands of women participate in offering special prayers and food to the deity.
temples.history: Chakkulathukavu Temple is believed to be over 3,000 years old and is one of the most revered Bhagavathy temples in Kerala. The temple is famous for its Pongala festival, during which devotees prepare offerings to seek the goddess's blessings. The temple is situated on the banks of the Pampa River, adding to its serene and divine atmosphere.

temples.name: Chettikulangara Devi Temple
temples.text: This temple is dedicated to Goddess Bhagavathy and is famous for the Kettukazhcha festival, where massive temple chariots and effigies are paraded through the streets.
temples.history: Chettikulangara Devi Temple is known for its spectacular Kettukazhcha festival, a visual extravaganza where large chariots, horses, and human figures are displayed in a grand procession. The temple's origins date back to ancient times, and it is believed to be a powerful center of Shakti worship in Kerala. The temple follows the unique rituals and traditions of the region, blending elements of Hindu and folk culture.

temples.name: Chottanikkara Temple
temples.text: One of the most significant temples in Kerala, Chottanikkara Temple is dedicated to Goddess Bhagavathy, revered for her healing powers, especially in curing mental illnesses.
temples.history: The Chottanikkara Temple is one of Kerala's most famous temples, where devotees seek relief from ailments and mental disturbances. The presiding deity is worshipped as Rajarajeswari (Durga) during the day and as Bhadrakali in the evening. The temple’s rituals include exorcisms and spiritual healing, attracting thousands of devotees. Its history is linked to ancient tantric traditions and is deeply rooted in Kerala’s spiritual heritage.

temples.name: Ettumanoor Mahadevar Temple
temples.text: The Ettumanoor Mahadevar Temple is a prominent Shiva temple in Kerala, known for its beautiful architecture and rich traditions. The deity worshipped here is Lord Shiva.
temples.history: The temple has a history dating back to ancient times and is famous for its murals, particularly the 'Pradosha Nritham' painting of Lord Shiva. It is believed that Adi Shankaracharya visited the temple and composed devotional hymns here.

temples.name: Ernakulam Shiva Temple
temples.text: Ernakulam Shiva Temple is an ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, situated in the heart of Ernakulam city. The temple is revered for its unique east-facing sanctum.
temples.history: The temple is believed to have been established centuries ago and is closely associated with the history of the Cochin royal family. It stands as a significant pilgrimage center in Kerala.

temples.name: Guruvayur Temple
temples.text: Guruvayur Temple is one of the most important Krishna temples in India, attracting millions of devotees annually. The main deity worshipped here is Lord Krishna, known as Guruvayurappan.
temples.history: The temple is said to be over 5,000 years old and is considered the 'Dwarka of the South.' Legends say that the idol was worshipped by Lord Krishna himself before being brought to Kerala. It is a major center of Vaishnavite worship.

temples.name: Kadampuzha Devi Temple
temples.text: Kadampuzha Devi Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Durga in her fierce form as Kiratha Parvathi.
temples.history: This temple is unique as it does not have an idol, but instead, the presence of the goddess is worshipped through a hole in the ground. It is believed that Adi Shankaracharya consecrated the temple. The temple is famous for its rituals like 'Poomoodal,' in which the deity is adorned with flowers.

temples.name: Kanadikavu Shree Vishnumaya Kuttichathan Swamy Temple
temples.text: This temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnumaya, also known as Kuttichathan, who is believed to be a divine protector and problem solver for devotees.
temples.history: The temple has been a major center for Tantric worship and is known for its powerful rituals. Devotees come here seeking solutions to problems and guidance through divine intervention.

temples.name: Kodungallur Bhagavathy Temple
temples.text: The Kodungallur Bhagavathy Temple is one of the most famous temples in Kerala dedicated to Goddess Bhadrakali. The temple is known for its grand Bharani festival.
temples.history: This temple is believed to have been built by Chera king Cheran Senkuttuvan. It has a deep connection with Kerala’s history and is associated with many legends and powerful rituals.

temples.name: Koodalmanikyam Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Bharatha, the brother of Lord Rama, Koodalmanikyam Temple is one of the rare temples in India that worships Bharatha as the presiding deity. It is located in Irinjalakuda, Thrissur district.
temples.history: Koodalmanikyam Temple is an ancient temple with significant historical importance. It is believed to date back to over a thousand years. The temple is unique as it does not have sub-deities, and its rituals differ from other temples. The annual festival, lasting ten days, attracts devotees from across the state.

temples.name: Kottiyoor Temple
temples.text: Kottiyoor Temple, also known as the 'Varanasi of the South,' is a revered Shiva temple located in Kannur district. It consists of Akkare Kottiyoor and Ikkare Kottiyoor, where annual rituals take place.
temples.history: The temple is associated with the Daksha Yaga legend. It is believed that Goddess Sati self-immolated at this sacred site, and Lord Shiva arrived here in fury. This temple plays a significant role in Hindu mythology and has been a major pilgrimage center for centuries.

temples.name: Lokanarkavu Temple
temples.text: Lokanarkavu Temple is dedicated to Goddess Durga and is located in Vadakara, Kozhikode district. The temple is closely associated with the legendary martial art form, Kalaripayattu.
temples.history: Lokanarkavu Temple has a rich history linked to the Vadakkan Pattukal ballads of Northern Kerala. It was the preferred worship place of the great warrior Thacholi Othenan. The temple’s murals and carvings reflect its ancient origins, and its annual festival draws devotees and art lovers alike.

temples.name: Mannarasala Snake Temple
temples.text: The Mannarasala Snake Temple is a unique pilgrimage site dedicated to serpent worship, located in Haripad, Kerala. The temple is renowned for its thousands of snake idols and is associated with the worship of Nagaraja (the serpent king). It is particularly famous for its rituals aimed at fertility and prosperity.
temples.history: The history of the Mannarasala Snake Temple is deeply rooted in Hindu mythology and local traditions. According to legend, a sage named Vasudeva performed penance at this location, and Lord Nagaraja appeared before him, granting divine blessings. The temple was later established as a center for serpent worship. Unlike most temples, Mannarasala is managed by a Brahmin woman known as 'Valiya Amma,' who plays a significant role in temple rituals. Devotees believe that prayers at this temple bring prosperity and protection from snake-related afflictions.

temples.name: Muthappan Temple
temples.text: The Muthappan Temple, also known as Parassinikadavu Muthappan Temple, is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Sree Muthappan, a deity representing Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. It is located in Kannur district, Kerala. The temple is known for its unique rituals and the Theyyam performance that is integral to worship here.
temples.history: Unlike other temples in Kerala, the Muthappan Temple follows a non-Brahminical tradition of worship. It is believed that Muthappan was a divine incarnation who traveled across Kerala, blessing devotees and challenging societal norms. The temple does not follow the typical idol-worship system; instead, devotees witness the divine through the traditional Theyyam performance. Offerings at the temple include fish and toddy, which is unusual for a Hindu temple. It is a popular destination for those seeking divine justice and blessings.

temples.name: Oachira Temple
temples.text: Oachira Temple, located in the Kollam district of Kerala, is a prominent pilgrimage site dedicated to Parabrahman, the formless supreme consciousness. Unlike conventional temples, Oachira Temple has no sanctum sanctorum or idols, emphasizing meditation and self-realization.
temples.history: The temple's origins trace back centuries and are closely associated with the Advaita philosophy. It is believed that the temple has existed since ancient times as a spiritual center rather than a structured temple. The annual Oachira Kali festival commemorates a historic battle and features a grand spectacle of mock battles performed in a waterlogged paddy field. This temple is a rare example of an open-worship concept in Hindu tradition.

temples.name: Padmanabhaswamy Temple
temples.text: The Padmanabhaswamy Temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and is one of the most famous temples in Kerala, located in Thiruvananthapuram.
temples.history: The temple has a rich history dating back to the 8th century and is built in the Dravidian style of architecture. It is one of the 108 Divya Desams of Lord Vishnu. The temple is renowned for its immense wealth, discovered in secret vaults, making it one of the richest places of worship in the world.

temples.name: Parumala Valiya Panayannarkavu Devi Temple
temples.text: This temple is dedicated to Goddess Durga and is located in the Pathanamthitta district of Kerala.
temples.history: The Parumala Valiya Panayannarkavu Devi Temple is one of the ancient temples associated with the rich traditions of Kerala. It is known for its unique rituals and the annual festival that attracts thousands of devotees.

temples.name: Payammal Shatrughna Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Shatrughna, this temple is one of the rare temples in India devoted to the youngest brother of Lord Rama.
temples.history: The Payammal Shatrughna Temple is part of the Nalambalam pilgrimage, which includes temples of Lord Rama and his three brothers. It has historical and spiritual significance, attracting devotees seeking blessings from Lord Shatrughna.

temples.name: Pazhavangadi Ganapathy Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Ganesha, this temple is located in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. The temple is famous for its unique rituals and traditions, including the breaking of coconuts as an offering to Lord Ganesha.
temples.history: The Pazhavangadi Ganapathy Temple was originally constructed by the soldiers of the Travancore army. The idol of Lord Ganesha was initially housed in Padmanabhapuram and later shifted to its present location in Thiruvananthapuram. The temple is known for its Dravidian architectural style and the presence of 32 different forms of Ganesha depicted within the temple premises. It is a revered site for devotees seeking blessings for prosperity and the removal of obstacles.

temples.name: Peruvanam Mahadeva Temple
temples.text: This ancient temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is located in Cherpu, Thrissur district. The temple is one of the oldest in Kerala and is known for its grand architecture and spiritual significance.
temples.history: The Peruvanam Mahadeva Temple has a history spanning over a thousand years. It is believed to be one of the 108 Shiva temples established by Sage Parasurama. The temple is renowned for its unique customs, including the famous Peruvanam Pooram festival, which attracts thousands of devotees and tourists. The temple structure showcases Kerala's traditional architectural style, featuring intricate wooden carvings and a vast courtyard. The sanctum houses a self-manifested (swayambhu) Shiva Lingam, making it a powerful center of worship for devotees.

temples.name: Pisharikavu Temple, Koyilandy
temples.text: The Pisharikavu Temple is a revered Hindu temple located in Koyilandy, Kerala. The presiding deity is Goddess Durga, worshipped as Pisharikavilamma. The temple is known for its unique rituals and vibrant annual festivals, attracting devotees from all over the region.
temples.history: The Pisharikavu Temple has a rich history dating back several centuries. It is believed that the idol of Goddess Durga was self-manifested, and the temple has been a significant spiritual center for the local community. The temple follows traditional Kerala temple architecture and rituals. The annual festival, celebrated with great enthusiasm, includes Theyyam performances and other cultural events.

temples.name: Rajarajeshwara Temple
temples.text: The Rajarajeshwara Temple is a famous Shiva temple located in Taliparamba, Kerala. It is considered one of the most sacred Shiva temples in South India and is renowned for its spiritual significance and grand architecture.
temples.history: The temple is believed to have been constructed over 1000 years ago and has been a center of Shaivite worship ever since. According to legend, the original Shiva Lingam was installed by Lord Parashurama. The temple has undergone several renovations, with contributions from various dynasties, including the Cholas and the Zamorins. Devotees believe that prayers offered here are highly auspicious and bring immense blessings.

temples.name: Sabarimala Temple
temples.text: Sabarimala Temple is one of the most famous pilgrimage centers in India, dedicated to Lord Ayyappa. Located in the Western Ghats, the temple attracts millions of devotees every year, especially during the Mandalam-Makaravilakku season.
temples.history: The origins of the Sabarimala Temple date back to ancient times. According to mythology, Lord Ayyappa meditated at this site after defeating the demoness Mahishi. The temple follows strict pilgrimage rules, with devotees undergoing a 41-day Vratham (penance) before visiting. The temple remains open only during specific periods, and the trek to the shrine through dense forests is a significant aspect of the pilgrimage.

temples.name: Sree Poornathrayeesa Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Vishnu in the form of Santhanagopala Moorthy, the temple is located in Tripunithura, Ernakulam district of Kerala.
temples.history: Sree Poornathrayeesa Temple is one of the most famous temples in Kerala, believed to have been established by Arjuna, one of the Pandavas. The deity here, Lord Vishnu, is worshipped as the protector of children. The temple is renowned for its grand festivals, especially Vrishchikotsavam, which attracts thousands of devotees. The temple is also unique as it allows elephants inside the sanctum during festivals, a rare tradition in Kerala temples.

temples.name: Sreenarayanapuram Temple
temples.text: A prominent Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, located in Kerala.
temples.history: Sreenarayanapuram Temple is a historically significant Vishnu temple known for its beautiful architecture and religious importance. It is visited by numerous devotees and is associated with many local legends that highlight its spiritual power and influence over the region.

temples.name: Tali Shiva Temple
temples.text: A famous Shiva temple located in Kozhikode district of Kerala.
temples.history: Tali Shiva Temple is an ancient temple that dates back to the 14th century and was built under the guidance of the Zamorins. The temple is known for its intricate wooden carvings and traditional Kerala-style architecture. The annual Shivaratri festival is a major attraction, drawing thousands of devotees each year.

temples.name: Thirumoozhikkulam Lakshmana Perumal Temple
temples.text: The temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu, worshipped here as Lakshmana Perumal. It is one of the 108 Divya Desams, the sacred shrines of Vishnu, revered by the Alvars. The temple is situated in Thirumoozhikkulam, Ernakulam district, Kerala.
temples.history: This ancient temple is believed to have been established during the Treta Yuga and is closely associated with the epic Ramayana. According to legend, Lord Rama and his brothers established temples in Kerala, with Lakshmana enshrined here. The temple's inscriptions and architectural features suggest significant renovations during the rule of the Chera and later Travancore kings.

temples.name: Thirunakkara Mahadevar Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Shiva, Thirunakkara Mahadevar Temple is a famous temple located in Kottayam town. The temple is known for its grand festivals and traditional Kerala-style architecture.
temples.history: The temple was built in the 16th century by the Thekkumkur kings. It played a significant role in the cultural and religious landscape of central Kerala. The annual Aaraattu festival, featuring traditional Kathakali performances and processions, attracts numerous devotees.

temples.name: Thrikodithanam Mahavishnu Temple
temples.text: One of the five ancient 'Pancha Pandava' temples in Kerala, Thrikodithanam Mahavishnu Temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and is situated in Changanassery, Kottayam district.
temples.history: The temple is associated with the Mahabharata and is believed to have been established by Sahadeva, one of the Pandavas. It has rich inscriptions and architectural elements dating back to the medieval period. It is part of the famous Divya Desams and has been revered in Tamil Vaishnavite literature.

temples.name: Thirumandhamkunnu Temple
temples.text: Thirumandhamkunnu Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Bhagavathi, located in Angadipuram, Malappuram district, Kerala.
temples.history: The Thirumandhamkunnu Temple has a rich history dating back centuries. It is believed to have been established by King Mandhata of the Surya Vamsa dynasty. The temple is particularly famous for its association with the legend of Goddess Bhagavathi, who is said to have fought and defeated the demon Daruka at this sacred site. Over the years, the temple has served as a cultural and spiritual center, attracting devotees from across the region. The temple is renowned for its annual Pooram festival, which features grand processions and traditional performances.

temples.name: Thirunelli Temple
temples.text: Thirunelli Temple is an ancient temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, situated in the Wayanad district of Kerala, within the Brahmagiri hills.
temples.history: Thirunelli Temple is often referred to as the 'Kashi of the South' due to its religious significance. According to legend, the temple was consecrated by Lord Brahma himself, making it one of the most sacred Vishnu temples in India. The temple is famous for its association with the ritual of 'Pind Daan,' a Hindu funeral rite for departed souls. Set amidst the picturesque Brahmagiri hills, this temple has been a pilgrimage site for devotees for centuries. Various ancient inscriptions and references in historical texts highlight its importance throughout Kerala’s history.

temples.name: Thiruvanchikulam Temple
temples.text: Thiruvanchikulam Temple is a historic Shiva temple located in Kodungallur, Thrissur district, Kerala.
temples.history: Thiruvanchikulam Temple is one of the oldest Shiva temples in Kerala, with a history spanning over 2,000 years. It was once the royal temple of the Chera dynasty, one of the prominent ruling families of ancient Kerala. The temple is renowned for its depiction in Tamil Sangam literature, which dates back to early medieval times. It is also closely linked with the Shaivite saints and their devotional hymns. The temple hosts the annual Maha Shivaratri festival, drawing thousands of devotees. The temple premises house multiple smaller shrines dedicated to various deities, making it a significant pilgrimage site.

temples.name: Thriprayar Temple
temples.text: Thriprayar Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Rama, located in the Thrissur district of Kerala, India.
temples.history: Thriprayar Temple is one of the most significant temples dedicated to Lord Rama in Kerala. The temple's presiding deity, Lord Rama, is worshipped in a majestic form, holding a bow and garlanded with Salagrama stones. The temple is believed to have been built during the early medieval period and is associated with several legends from the Ramayana. The idol of Lord Rama here is unique, featuring attributes of Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma, making it a rare representation. It is part of the Nalambalam pilgrimage, which includes temples of Rama, Bharata, Lakshmana, and Shatrughna. The temple is well known for its grand annual festival and the spectacular Pooram celebrations.

temples.name: Tirunavaya Temple
temples.text: Tirunavaya Temple, also known as Nava Mukunda Temple, is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, located in the Malappuram district of Kerala, India.
temples.history: Tirunavaya Temple has a rich history dating back several centuries and is closely associated with the Mamankam festival, a grand traditional event held every twelve years in medieval Kerala. The temple is believed to be over a thousand years old and is famous for its association with ancestor worship. It is located on the banks of the Bharathapuzha River, a sacred site for performing rituals for the departed souls. The temple enshrines Lord Vishnu as Nava Mukunda, and the deity is said to have appeared here in nine different forms before settling in the present idol. The temple also has shrines dedicated to Lord Ganapathi and Goddess Lakshmi.

temples.name: Vadakkunnathan Temple
temples.text: Vadakkunnathan Temple is a major Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in the city of Thrissur, Kerala, India.
temples.history: Vadakkunnathan Temple is one of the oldest and most prominent Shiva temples in Kerala. It is said to have been built by Lord Parasurama, the legendary creator of Kerala. The temple is an excellent example of classic Kerala architecture, featuring grand murals and majestic towers. The temple is famous for hosting the grand Thrissur Pooram festival, one of the biggest temple festivals in Kerala, attracting thousands of devotees and tourists. Vadakkunnathan Temple is recognized as a UNESCO cultural heritage site, reflecting its historical and architectural significance.

temples.name: Vaikom Mahadevar Temple
temples.text: Vaikom Mahadevar Temple is an important Shiva temple, located in the Kottayam district of Kerala, India.
temples.history: Vaikom Mahadevar Temple is one of the oldest temples in Kerala, with a history dating back over a thousand years. The temple is revered as one of the Shiva temples associated with the legendary 'Ashta Vaikom' (Eight Shiva Temples). The deity is believed to grant blessings to devotees regardless of caste and creed, making it an important center for spiritual inclusivity. The temple gained historical significance during the Vaikom Satyagraha (1924-25), a movement for temple entry rights for all castes, which played a crucial role in Kerala's social reform movements. The grand Vaikathashtami festival held annually is a major attraction for pilgrims.

temples.name: Valayanad Devi Temple
temples.text: Valayanad Devi Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Bhadrakali, located in Kozhikode district, Kerala, India.
temples.history: Valayanad Devi Temple is one of the few temples in Kerala where Goddess Bhadrakali is worshipped in her fierce form. The temple is believed to have been established by the Zamorins of Kozhikode, who were great patrons of the temple. It is said that the idol of the Goddess was brought from Kanchipuram and consecrated in Kerala. The temple follows the Shakteya tradition of worship and has a unique architectural style. The annual festival at Valayanad Devi Temple is celebrated with grand rituals, including Theyyam performances, which are an integral part of the temple's culture.

temples.name: Vazhappally Maha Siva Temple
temples.text: Vazhappally Maha Siva Temple is an ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in the Alappuzha district of Kerala, India.
temples.history: Vazhappally Maha Siva Temple is a historically significant temple, dating back to the early medieval period. The temple is well known for the Vazhappally Copper Plate, one of the oldest known inscriptions in Kerala, which provides valuable historical insights into the region's governance and religious traditions. The temple follows the traditional Kerala temple architecture, and its rituals and poojas are conducted according to the Tantric traditions. The annual festival at Vazhappally is a grand celebration that attracts a large number of devotees from all over Kerala.

temples.name: Bijasan Mata Temple, Indore
temples.text: Bijasan Mata Temple is one of the temples of the Hindu goddess Durga, situated in Indore District of Madhya Pradesh, India. This temple is built in the year 1760 by Shivaji Rao Holkar. This temple is visited by thousands of devotees during Navaratri.
temples.history: The temple is believed to be several centuries old, serving as a spiritual center for devotees seeking blessings and protection from the goddess. Bijasan Mata is considered a form of Maa Durga, symbolizing strength, prosperity, and divine grace. The temple is particularly crowded during Navratri, as thousands of devotees come to offer prayers and perform special rituals. Local legends state that the temple's location was once a meditation site for sages and saints, who worshipped the goddess here.

temples.name: Chaturbhuj Temple (Orchha)
temples.text: Chaturbhuj Temple, dedicated to Vishnu, is situated at Orchha in Madhya Pradesh, India. The name Chaturbhuj is a combination of 'chatur' meaning 'four' and 'bhuj' meaning 'arms' which literally translates to 'one who has four arms' and refers to Rama an Avatar of Vishnu. The temple has a complex multi-storied structural view which is a blend of temple, fort and palatial architectural features.
temples.history: The temple was constructed by the Bundela Rajputs of the kingdom of Orchha during the reign of Mughal emperor Akbar. Its construction was begun by Madhukar Shah and completed by his son, Vir Singh Deo in the 16th century. Madhukar Shah built the temple for his wife, Rani Ganeshkuwari. According to a local legend, the temple was built after the queen had a 'dream visitation' by Lord Rama directing her to build a temple for Him; while Madhukar Shah was a devotee of Krishna, his wife's dedication was to Rama. Following the approval to build the Chaturbhuja Temple, the queen went to Ayodhya to obtain an image of Lord Rama that was to be enshrined in her new temple. When she came back from Ayodhya with the image of Rama, initially she kept the idol in her palace, called Rani Mahal, as the Chaturbhuj Temple was still under construction. She was, however, unaware of an injunction that the image to be deified in a temple could not be kept in a palace. Once the temple construction was completed and the idol of the lord had to be moved for installation at the Chatrubhuj Temple, it refused to be shifted from the palace. Hence, instead of the Chaturbuj temple, the Rama's idol remained in the palace whereas the Chaturbhuj Temple remained without an idol in its sanctum. As Rama was worshiped in the palace it was converted into the Ram Raja Temple; it is the only shrine in the country where Rama is worshiped as a king.

temples.name: Chintaman Ganesh Temple, Ujjain
temples.text: Chintaman Ganesh is the biggest temple of Lord Ganesha in Ujjain of Madhya Pradesh, India. This temple is built across the Kshipra river on the Fatehabad railway line, and is located about 7 km far south-westerly to the Ujjain town. The temple is located now in the middle of the town's market.
temples.history: The temple dates back to 11th and 12th centuries when the Paramaras ruled over Malwa. It is also believed that the original temple dates back to the Ramayan age and the temple is stablished by Sita.

temples.name: Dada Darbar (Khandwa)
temples.text: Dada Darbar is a Hindu Temple in Khandwa, Nimar region, Madhya Pradesh, India. It is named after Dadaji Dhuniwale. Dada Darbar is built at the memorial place of Dadaji Dhuniwale. There are innumerable devotees of 'Dadaji' in India. There are twenty-seven Dham's in India and abroad in the name of Dadaji Dhuniwale.
temples.history: Dada Darbar in Khandwa, Madhya Pradesh, is a sacred shrine dedicated to Saint Shri Dadaji Dhuniwale, a revered spiritual guru and mystic known for his divine powers and miracles. It is one of the most famous pilgrimage sites in Khandwa, attracting devotees from across India.

temples.name: Devi Jagadambi Temple
temples.text: Devi Jagadambika Temple or Jagadambika Temple is one of a group of about 25 temples at Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh, India. Along with the other temples at Khajuraho, the temple was listed as a World Heritage Site because of its outstanding architecture, art, and historical importance. The temples of Khajuraho were built by the rulers of the Chandela dynasty between the 10th and the 12th centuries.
temples.history: The Devi Jagadambi Temple is one of the Khajuraho group of monuments that were built during the rule of the Chandela dynasty. The building activity started almost immediately after the rise of their power, throughout their kingdom to be later known as Bundelkhand. Most temples were built during the reigns of the Hindu kings Yashovarman and Dhanga. Yashovarman's legacy is best exhibited by the Lakshmana Temple. Vishvanatha temple best highlights King Dhanga's reign. The largest and currently most famous surviving temple is Kandariya Mahadeva built in the reign of King Vidyadhara. The temple inscriptions suggest many of the currently surviving temples were complete between 970 and 1030 CE, with further temples completed during the following decades.

temples.name: Gajanan Maharaj Temple, Indore
temples.text: Shri Sant Gajanan Maharaj Temple Indore is situated at Paliwal Nagar in Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India.
temples.history: 'Sarv jan Hitaaye, sarv jan sukham' this sentence motivated the establishment Shri Sadguru Gajanan Maharaj Sevashram at Indore. In the year 1988 Mr. Paliwal donated the area of 13,000 square feet (1,200 m2), on the auspicious day of Basant panchami ritual ceremony of 'Bhumi pujan' was done under the guidance of Shri Guru baba and in the presence of the Gajanan family. After 'Bhumi pujan' two rooms were constructed. In one of the two rooms big photo of Shri Gajanan Maharaj was being placed and worshiped by devotees. In the year 1992 the Thursday 'Maha Prasad' started, around 13 devotees took the 'Maha prasad' on the first day.

temples.name: Jatashankar
temples.text: Jatashankar is a natural cave and Hindu shrine located north of Pachmarhi, in Narmadapuram district, Madhya Pradesh, India. Jatashankar is located in a deep ravine with enormous boulders perched above. The cave contains stalagmites which are revered as naturally formed lingams. The cave serves as a shrine to the deity Shiva and is a popular destination for pilgrims. Jata means matted hair and Shankara is another name of Shiva. There are two ponds fed by springs found in the locality, one of cold water and the other one of hot water. The cave structure is said to resemble the hundred-headed Shesha, the serpent-mount of Vishnu.
temples.history: Jatashankar Temple is a revered cave temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located near Pachmarhi in the Hoshangabad district of Madhya Pradesh. It is a significant pilgrimage site and a natural wonder, attracting devotees and nature lovers alike.

temples.name: Kal Bhairav Temple, Ujjain
temples.text: Kal Bhairav temple is a Hindu temple located in the Ujjain city of Madhya Pradesh, India. It is dedicated to Kal Bhairav, the guardian deity of the city. Located on the banks of the Shipra River, it is one of the most active temples in the city, visited by hundreds of devotees daily. Liquor is one of the offerings made to the temple deity.
temples.history: The present-day temple structure was built over the remains of an older temple. The original temple is believed to have been built by an obscure king named Bhadrasen. It has been mentioned in the Avanti Khanda of the Skanda Purana. Images of Shiva, Parvati, Vishnu and Ganesha belonging to the Paramara period have been recovered from the place. The temple walls were once decorated with Malwa paintings. However, only traces of these paintings are visible now.

temples.name: Kandariya Mahadeva Temple
temples.text: The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple, meaning 'the Great God of the Cave', is the largest and most ornate Hindu temple in the medieval temple group found at Khajuraho in Madhya Pradesh, India. It is considered one of the best examples of temples preserved from the medieval period in India. Because of its outstanding preservation and testimony to the Chandela culture, the temple was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1986.
temples.history: Khajuraho was once the capital of the Chandela dynasty. The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple, one of the best examples of temples preserved from the medieval period in India, is the largest of the western group of temples in the Khajuraho complex which was built by the Chandela rulers. Shiva is the chief deity in the temple deified in the sanctum sanctorum. The Kandariya Mahadeva temple was built during the reign of Vidyadhara. At various periods of the reign of this dynasty many famous temples dedicated to Vishnu, Shiva, Surya, Shakti of the Hindu religion and also for the Thirthankaras of Jain religion were built. Vidhyadhara, also known as Bida in the recordings of the Muslim historian Ibn-al-Athir was a powerful ruler who fought Mahmud of Ghazni in the first offensive launched by the latter in 1019.

temples.name: Khajrana Ganesh Temple
temples.text: Khajrana Ganesh Temple is a Hindu temple complex, situated in Khajrana area of Indore in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, India. The main temple in the complex is dedicated to Lord Ganesha. It was built by Maharani Ahilyabai Holkar of the Holkar Dynasty.
temples.history: This temple was built in 1735 by Maharani Ahilyabai Holkar of the Holkar dynasty, who retrieved the idol of god Ganesha from a well where it had been hidden to keep it safe from the Mughal ruler Aurangzeb. The devotees circle around the temple and tie a thread to pray to Lord Ganesha for the successful completion of their work. It is said that the ancient idol in the temple was seen in a dream of a local priest, Pandit Mangal Bhatt. The temple is still managed by the Bhatt family.

temples.name: Khajuraho Group of Monuments
temples.text: The Khajuraho Group of Monuments are a group of Hindu and Jain temples in Chhatarpur district, Madhya Pradesh, India. They are about 175 kilometres (109 mi) southeast of Jhansi, 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) from Khajwa, 9 kilometres (5.6 mi) from Rajnagar, and 49 kilometres (30 mi) from district headquarter Chhatarpur. The temples are famous for their Nagara-style architectural symbolism and a few erotic sculptures.
temples.history: The Khajuraho group of monuments was built during the rule of the Chandela dynasty. The building activity started almost immediately after the rise of their power, throughout their kingdom to be later known as Bundelkhand.[16] Most temples were built during the reigns of the Hindu kings Yashovarman and Dhanga. Yashovarman's legacy is best exhibited by the Lakshmana Temple. Vishvanatha temple best highlights King Dhanga's reign. The largest and currently most famous surviving temple is Kandariya Mahadeva built in the reign of King Vidyadhara. The temple inscriptions suggest many of the currently surviving temples were complete between 970 and 1030 CE, with further temples completed during the following decades.

temples.name: Mahakaleshwar Jyotirlinga
temples.text: Mahakaleshwar Jyotirlinga is a Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva and is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas, shrines which are said to be the most sacred abodes of Shiva. It is located in the ancient city of Ujjain in the state of Madhya Pradesh, India. The temple is situated on the side of the holy river Shipra. The presiding deity, Shiva in the lingam form is believed to be Swayambhu, deriving currents of power from within itself as against the other images and lingams that are ritually established and invested with mantra-shakti.
temples.history: The temple complex was destroyed by Iltutmish during his raid of Ujjain in 1234–35. The Jyotirlinga was dismantled and believed to be thrown into a nearby 'Kotiteerth Kunda' with the Jaladhari stolen during the invasion. It was later reconstructed and revived by Maratha Diwan Ramachandra Baba Sukthankar. It was again attacked by Jalaluddin Khilji and Alauddin Khilji.

temples.name: Mohas Hanuman Mandir
temples.text: Mohas Hanuman Mandir is a Hanuman temple located in Mohas village, which is 35 km away from Katni, Madhya Pradesh, India. Mohas village's people believe that by eating the herbs found in the temple, broken bones get healed by the blessings of the God.
temples.history: Mohas village's people believe that Adhari Lal Patel was the father of the priest of the temple, Sarman Patel, was suggested by a sage in the forest to do good to the people by providing them some herbs. So, he started giving herbs to people. The place where he gave herbs later developed to a temple.

temples.name: Omkareshwar Temple
temples.text: Omkareshwar Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, located in Mandhata, nearby Khandwa city in Khandwa district of the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. It is one of the 12 revered Jyotirlinga shrines of Shiva. It is on an island called Mandhata, near Khandwa city in the Narmada River at Khandwa district in Madhya Pradesh, India; the shape of the island is said to be like the Devanagari ॐ symbol.
temples.history: The temple is said to have been built by the Paramara Kings of Malwa in the 11th century CE. After the Paramara kings, the administration of the temple was taken over by the Chauhan rulers. In the 13th century CE, the temple suffered destruction and loot by Muslim invaders starting with Mahmud Ghazni. Nevertheless, the temple remained intact without complete destruction. The temple was under the Chauhan Kings during the entire Mughal rule, without much renovation. In the 18th century, the temple was rebuilt by the Holkar rulers. The construction of the same was started by the 1st Holkar Queen,Gautama Bai Holkar and later completed by her daughter-in-law Devi Ahilyabai Holkar. The temple came under the British rule during the colonial era. After Independence in 1947, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) took over the responsibility of the temple with the help of the Khandwa administration.

temples.name: Pashupatinath Temple, Mandsaur
temples.text: Pashupatinath Temple at Mandsaur, also referred to as the Mandsaur Shiva temple, is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva in Mandsaur, Madhya Pradesh, India. It belongs to Pashupatinath tradition which is one of 6 major tradition within Shaivism. It is located on Shivna River, and is known for its eight-faced Shiva Linga. The temple sculpture is dated to the 5th or 6th century based on inscriptions, with some referring to the site as Dashapura. It is near the Rajasthan border in the historic region of Malwa, about 200 kilometres (120 mi) from Indore, about 340 kilometres (210 mi) west of Udaigiri Caves and about 220 kilometres (140 mi) east of Shamalaji ancient sites, both a significant source of Gupta Empire era archaeological discoveries. The site has been important to dating and the architectural studies of some distant sites such as the Elephanta Caves.
temples.history: The site's history is traceable to the 2nd-century CE when it was already a Hindu pilgrimage site. It is mentioned by the ancient Indian poet Kalidasa, who praises the women of Dashapura as 'so practiced in their seductive movements'. Ten inscriptions found in the area suggest the Mandsaur site was an important cultural and religious center in the first half of the 1st millennium CE. Nine of these inscriptions are Sanskrit poems, most dated between 404 and 487 CE, and all include invocations to Hindu gods such as Vasudeva and Shiva in various forms. They mention kings of Gupta Empire era, as well as temples of Dashapura. Together with dozens of temples discovered at a number of sites in western Madhya Pradesh, eastern Rajasthan and northern Gujarat region, the Mandsaur site with the Shiva Stele and the temple reflect what Stella Kramrisch called one of the 'Western schools' of ancient and early medieval Indian art. James Harle concurs and includes the nearby Sondni and Kilchipura sites to the Western school along with regions farther west. According to Harle, the sculpture from the temple and other archaeological findings such as the Mandsaur inscriptions – one of which he calls 'the longest and certainly the most beautiful of the Gupta inscriptions' – reflect the 'flavor of life at its best in Gupta times'.

temples.name: Pitambara Peeth
temples.text: Shri Peetambra Peetha is a complex of Hindu temples, located in the city of Datia, in the Madhya Pradesh state of central India. It was, according to many legends 'Tapasthali' of many mythological as well as real life people. The Shivling of shree Vankhandeswar Shiva is alleged to be from the times of Mahabharata. It is primarily a Shaktipeeth place of worship. Many people come here for worship on Saturday, there is the biggest crowd here.
temples.history: The Pitambara Peeth was established by Swami Ji Maharaj, a great spiritual saint and Tantric in the 20th century. He was believed to have divine knowledge of Shakti Sadhana (Tantric practices) and chose this location for Maa Pitambara’s worship. The temple is an important center for Tantric studies, attracting seekers of divine wisdom, victory in battles, and legal success. Goddess Baglamukhi (Pitambara) is one of the ten Mahavidyas, worshipped for protection, justice, and removal of enemies. The Gita Press Gorakhpur’s founder, Jaydayal Goyandka, was a devotee of the Peeth and contributed to its development.

temples.name: Ram Raja Temple
temples.text: The Ram Raja Temple is a temple in Orchha, Madhya Pradesh, India. It is a sacred Hindu pilgrimage and receives devotees in large numbers regularly and is also commonly known as Orchha Temple. The annual domestic tourist number is around 650,000 and the foreign tourist number is around 25,000. The daily number of visitors to the temple range from 1500 to 3000 and on certain important Hindu festivals like the Makar Sankranti, Vasant Panchami, Shivratri, Ram Navami, Kartik Purnima and Vivaha Panchami the number of devotees who throng to Orchha range in thousands. In India this is the only temple where God Rama is worshiped as a king and that too in a palace. A Guard of Honour is held every day, police personnel have been designated as Guards at the temple, much in the manner of a king. The food and other amenities provided to the deity at the temple are a royal repast. Armed salutation is provided to God Ram every day.
temples.history: The story of Ram Raja Temple according to many local people goes like this: The King of Orchha Madhukar Shah Ju Dev (1554–1592) was a devotee of Banke Bhihari (God Krishna) of Brindavan while his wife Queen Ganesh Kunwari, also called Kamla Devi, was a devotee of God Ram. One day the King and the Queen went to God Krishna's temple but the temple had closed by that time. The queen urged the king to go back but the king wanted to stay. So both the king and queen decided to stay back. They joined a group of devotees who were singing and dancing in praise of God Krishna outside the temple. The king and queen also joined in the prayers and started to sing and dance. It is believed that God Krishna and Radha personified and danced with them and golden flowers were showered from the heavens at that moment.

temples.name: Sasbahu Temple, Gwalior
temples.text: Sas Bahu Temples, also called the Sas aur Bahu ke Mandir, Sas-Bahu Twin Temples, are the 11th-century twin temples in Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India. Within the Gwalior Fort complex and dedicated to Vishnu & Shiva, like most Hindu and Jain temples in this region, they were mostly in ruins and were badly damaged from numerous invasions and Hindu-Muslim wars in the region. They were built between 1090 - 1093 by King Mahipala of the Kachchhapaghata dynasty, the larger one was constructed for his wife and the smaller one was constructed for his daughter-in-law, according to an inscription found in the larger of the twin temple. The twin temples are situated in the Gwalior Fort.
temples.history: The temple was built in 1092 AD by King Mahipala of the Kachchhapaghata dynasty. The name 'Sasbahu' comes from Sahasrabahu, another name for Lord Vishnu, but over time, the name got associated with the Hindi words Saas and Bahu, leading to a popular local legend. The temple complex consists of two temples, one larger and one smaller, which is believed to have led to the name 'Sasbahu' —one temple for the mother-in-law and one for the daughter-in-law.

temples.name: Shri Kala Bhairava Nath Swami Temple
temples.text: Shri Kala Bhairava Nath Swami Temple is one of the most famous Hindu temples dedicated to lord Bhairava. It is located in the ancient village of Adegaon in Seoni district in the state of Madhya Pradesh, India.
temples.history: According to Hindu mythology, Kala Bhairava was created by Lord Shiva to punish Lord Brahma for his arrogance. In his anger, Kala Bhairava cut off one of Brahma’s five heads, and as a result, he was cursed to roam as a beggar with Brahma's skull (Kapala) stuck to his hand. He was finally freed from this curse when he reached Kashi (Varanasi), where he is still worshipped as the guardian deity. Many believe that the Kala Bhairava Nath Swami Temple is among the eight main Bhairava shrines (Ashta Bhairava) and that it holds mystical powers for protection, prosperity, and spiritual enlightenment.

temples.name: Shyam Kaka Temple
temples.text: Shyam Kaka Temple, temple of Hindu God Krishna, dating back to 1845 CE located in Shaka Jagir village in Rajgarh district, Madhya Pradesh, India. It is near Narsinghgarh, about 100 km from Bhopal. Despite being a temple of the Hindu god Krishna, there is a panel in the temple depicting six Muslim men dressed in long robes and traditional headgear, offering namaz. According to author Shalini Rai Narayan, it is one of the exceptional places, where religious beliefs and antagonistic holy men stood in solidarity. it was heavily damaged during the British raj heavy looting campaign were launched by the British to get to temples wealth and estimated amount of 123 kg gold was looted from the temple it was fully rebulided in August 1987 by bogriath gupta and his colleagues.it is still to this day missing some parts.
temples.history: The legend has it that a local ruler Shyam Dev Khinchi's wife Bhagali Devi left the palace after felling out with him and took shelter with Amara Singh Gurjar, a local chieftain. When Shyam dev was later killed in a battle, the queen ordered to make temple of lord Krishna in memory of her husband and Amara Singh Gurjar was anointed the head priest of Shyam kaka temple. Since then (1844–45), the Gurjars claim to have been priests of the temple.

temples.name: Gopinath Temple, Ningthoukhong
temples.text: Gopinath Temple, located in Ningthoukhong, Manipur, is a significant Vaishnav Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Gopinath (Krishna). It holds the distinction of being the second-largest temple in Manipur.
temples.history: The temple was built during the period when Vaishnavism became widely accepted in Manipur, primarily under the influence of King Garibaniwaz (Pamheiba) in the 18th century. The spread of Gaudiya Vaishnavism in Manipur, inspired by Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, played a crucial role in the temple's construction and prominence. Ningthoukhong, where the temple is located, was a significant site for Meitei kings, and the temple was established as a center for Krishna devotion in the region.

temples.name: Shree Govindajee Temple
temples.text: Shree Govindajee Temple is a Meitei Hindu temple, dedicated to Hindu deities Radha Krishna (Govindaji). It is the largest Vaishnava temple in Imphal district of Manipur, India. It was originally built in 1846 during the reign of Maharaja Nara Singh and later rebuilt by Maharaja Chandrakriti in 1876.
temples.history: Maharaja Nara Singh (1844-50 AD) of the Manipur kingdom commissioned the temple on 16 January 1846 and dedicated it to Shree Govindaji, which was their royal deity. The temple and the deities were substantially damaged during an earthquake of 1868. Consequently, the temple was rebuilt to its original design during the reign of Maharaja Chandrakriti (1859-1886) and was consecrated on 26 April 1876. However, during the Anglo Manipur war of 1891 the idols of the temple were moved to Kongma. In 1908, after the Maharaja Churchand Singh took up residence at his new palace the idols were also moved and reconsecrated in the present temple.

temples.name: Nartiang Durga Temple
temples.text: Nartiang Durga Temple is a 600-year-old temple located in the West Jaintia Hills district of Meghalaya in northeastern India. It is one of the 51 Shakti Peethas and is one of the holiest sites for devotees of the Shaktism sect of Hinduism. The Hindus in the Jaintia Hills of Meghalaya believes that this temple is the permanent abode of Goddess Durga. The temple draws a large number of pilgrims from all over the country on occasion of Durga Puja. The Shakti of Nartiang Devi shrine is worshipped as Jayanti and the Bhairava as Kamadishwar.
temples.history: Devi's left thigh is believed to have fallen at Nartiang in the Jaintia Hills. Hence the Goddess is known as Jainteshwari. The Jaintia king Jaso Manik (1606–1641) had married Lakshmi Narayana, the daughter of the Hindu Koch king Nara Narayana. It is believed that it was Lakshmi Narayana who had influenced the Jaintia Royalty to embrace Hinduism. King Dhan Manik had made Nartiang the summer capital of the Jaintia Kingdom about 600 years ago. One night, the goddess appeared to him in a dream and informed him of the significance of the place and asked him to build a temple in Her honour. Following this, the Jainteshwari temple in Nartiang was established. The strategic location of the temple and presence of weapons like cannons suggests that the temple must have been part of a fort of the Jaintia Kings.

temples.name: Devi Talab Mandir
temples.text: Devi Talab Mandir is a Hindu temple, located in Jalandhar, Punjab, India. The temple is devoted to Goddess Durga and is visited by thousands of pilgrims every year. It is regarded as one of the 51 Shakti Pithas in India. A model of the Amarnath Temple, dedicated to God Shiva, is located within the temple complex. There is an old temple dedicated to Goddess Kali located next to the Mandir. One of the main attractions of the temple is an ancient tank that holds great religious significance for Hindu devotees. The temple has intricate gold work both inside and on its top.
temples.history: Devi Talab Mandir is an ancient Hindu temple located in Jalandhar, Punjab, India, and is dedicated to Goddess Durga. It is one of the 51 Shakti Peethas, believed to be the spot where Sati’s right breast fell when Lord Shiva carried her body across the universe.

temples.name: Durgiana Temple
temples.text: Durgiana Temple or Shri Durgiana Mandir is a Hindu temple situated in the city of Amritsar in Punjab, India. Though a Hindu temple, its architecture is similar to the Sikh Harmandir Sahib. The temple derives its name from the Goddess Durga, the chief Goddess who is worshipped here. Murtis of Lakshmi and Vishnu are also located and worshipped in the temple.
temples.history: The Sri Durgiana temple is a very important temple for Hindus. In the courtyard of the temple is a tree where Lava and Kusha bound Hanuman after the captured challenge horse of the Ashvamedha yajna. Ikshvaku, the grandson of sun-god, performed a number of yagyas on this land. The original temple was built in 16th century. The architecture of Sri Durgiana Temple is similar to Shri Harmandir Sahib. It was built in 1921 by Guru Harsai Mal Kapoor in the architectural style of the Sikh Shri Harmandir Sahib. Harsai Mal was a descendant of Prithi Chand and hence Guru Ram Das. The grandchildren of Harsai Mal Kapoor is currently living in amritsar and one of caretakers of the idol of Harsai mal Kapoor.

temples.name: Jayanti Devi Temple
temples.text: Jayanti Devi Temple lies at Jayanti Majri village hillock, which is 15 km from Chandigarh in Mohali district of Punjab.
temples.history: Named after Jayanti, the goddess of victory. The Pandavas built a temple to Jayanti Devi around which came up the town of Jayantipuri.

temples.name: Julfa Mata Temple
temples.text: The Julfa Mata Temple is a Hindu temple in the town of Nangal, Rupnagar district, Punjab, in northern India. According to the story, there were demons who harassed gods over the Himalayan Mountains. The gods decided to destroy them. Lord Vishnu was leading them. The Gods focused their strengths in a huge flame which rose from the earth. Out of the fire a girl took birth and regarded as Adishakti (means first shakti). She grew up in the house of Prajapati Daksha. She used to be called as Sati. Later she became wife of Lord Shiva.
temples.history: According to Hindu mythology, the temple is associated with the legend of Goddess Sati. It is believed that when Sati self-immolated in response to her father Daksha's insult towards her husband, Lord Shiva, he carried her burning body across the universe. To pacify him, Lord Vishnu used his Sudarshan Chakra to dismember Sati's body, leading to the creation of 51 Shakti Peethas—sacred sites where her body parts fell. The term 'Julfa' translates to 'hair,' and it is believed that Sati's hair fell at the location of the Julfa Mata Temple, marking it as one of these Shakti Peethas.

temples.name: Maiser Khana
temples.text: Maiser Khana is a temple built to honour the Goddesses Durga and Jwala Ji. It is built 29 kilometers away from Bathinda, Punjab, India, on Bathinda-Mansa Road. Each year two grand melas are held here on Ashtami. According to a legend, long ago, a person called 'Kamala', having failed to undertake hazardous pilgrimage to far off Jwala ji,underwent a lifelong penance to honour Durga for her darshan and the goddess was pleased to grant him a vision twice a year, so two melas are held each year. People gather from almost all over from Punjab and even nearby states to join in singing hymns in praise of the deity. This is also considered important from political point of view because both Sikhs and Hindus gather with equal enthusiasm. As early as 1951 the devotees had requested Mahavir Dal to take over the shrine, which was decaying due to Government indifference.
temples.history: The temple's origins trace back to the spot where Kamala received the divine vision. Over time, the site gained prominence, and a temple was established to honor the goddesses. By 1951, the shrine had fallen into disrepair. Recognizing its spiritual significance, community leaders Radheshyam Budhlada, Jagannath Ji of Maur Mandi, and Hansraj Aggarwal spearheaded efforts to renovate and expand the temple. They mobilized resources and collaborated with esteemed architects to reconstruct the temple, restoring its prominence as a major pilgrimage center. ​

temples.name: Mukteshwar Mahadev Temple
temples.text: Mukteshwar Mahadev Temple, also known as Mukesaran Mandir, is a shrine to Shiva and man-made cave complex located near Pathankot City, Punjab, India. on Shahpur Kandi Dam road. It is a Hindu temple containing representations of Ganesha, Brahma, Vishnu, Hanuman, and Parvati. It is considered to be one of the most sacred places around Pathankot. According to legend, the Pandavas stayed in the caves for a night during their exile (Agayatwas), and it is said that some of the caves date to the time of the Mahabharata.
temples.history: There is a legend that the Lord Shiva slayed a demon here and granted him salvation (Mukti). In Sanskrit, the word Mukteshwar means 'God of Relief or 'Lord of Salvation', thus making this the 'Temple of Salvation'.

temples.name: Shanaleshwara Swayambhu Temple
temples.text: Shanaleshwara Swayambhu Temple dedicated to the worship of Lord Shiva. 'Shanaleshwara' means, the sign that is worshiped as Lord Shiva. It is situated at 7 Kilometre away in the Nalas village of Rajpura, Punjab. It is maintained by the ascetic sadhu's of Juna Akhara Foundation.
temples.history: According to the legend, a cow always showered own milk on the lingam. Nalas region was in jungle, at that time cowherds used to came to feed their cattle's.

temples.name: Shri Kali Devi Temple, Patiala
temples.text: Shri Kali Devi Temple is a Hindu temple in Patiala, Punjab, India. It was built by the Maharaja of Patiala in 1936. The Maharaja was inspired to build the temple and bring the six-foot-tall statues of Maa Kali and Paawan Jyot from Bengal to Patiala. Today, the temple is situated opposite the Baradari Gardens. Shri Kali Devi is a kul devi of many people. During the Navratras, the temple has many visitors over the course of nine days.
temples.history: Shri Kali Devi Temple was built by the Maharaja Bhupinder Singh of Patiala in 1936. The Maharaja was inspired to build the temple and bring the six-foot-tall statues of Maa Kali and Paawan Jyot from Bengal to Patiala. This large complex attracts devotees from distant places. A much older temple of Shri Raj Rajeshwari ji is also situated in the center of this complex. Because of Temple’s beautiful infrastructure, it has been declared a national monument. Devotees offer Mustard Oil, daal (lentils), sweets, coconuts, bangles, chunnis, goats, hens and liquor to the Divine Mother here.

temples.name: Suraj Kund Sunam
temples.text: Suraj Kund Mandir was a large Sun temple, located to the east of Sunam city (dated to the Vedic period), about 1.5 kilometres (0.93 miles) away in the tahsil and sub division of the Sangrur District in the Indian state of Punjab, was destroyed by Timur or Mohammad Ghaznavi. It is also said that Saraswati River was flowing nearby. The Suraj Kund is now in a dilapidated condition. It is situated on the Ludhiana-Hisar railway line, and is connected by road with Patiala (64 kilometres (40 miles)), Sangrur (19 kilometres (12 miles)), Bathinda (114 kilometres (71 miles)), Ludhiana (90 kilometres (56 miles)), and Chandigarh (120 kilometres (75 miles)).
temples.history: According to local legends, King Shobhan of Surajpur (now known as Sunam) constructed the temple near the Saraswati River around five to six thousand years ago. The temple's history is documented in the Imperial Gazetteer of Patiala and mentioned by the scholar Al-Biruni in his work 'Kitab-Ul-Hind.'' King Shobhan, a devout follower of the Sun deity, is said to have built this temple to protect his people from the malefic effects of Saturn (Shani).

temples.name: Pandori Dham
temples.text: Thakurdwara Bhagwan Narainji is a historical Hindu temple belonging to Ramanandi Sampradaya, located in the village Pandori Mahantan in Gurdaspur district of Punjab in India. It constitutes one of the fifty-two Vaishnav dvaras of Indian subcontinent into which Bairagis have been organized. The shrine was founded by Ramanandi saint Shri Bhagwanji and his disciple Shri Narainji after whom the shrine has been name.The temple is known for its spectacular Baisakhi fair.
temples.history: The Vaishnav establishment at Pandori Dham was founded by local Ramanandi saint Shri Bhagwanji who was a Dogra Khajuria Brahmin born at Kahnuwan town in Gurdaspur. As per local tradition, Shri Bhagwanji during his early years had met Ramanandi saint Shri Krishnadas Payahari of Galta dham in Rajasthan who had brought him into order of Ramanandi Vaishnavism. The shrine is also said to have won the allegiance of Hindu princely states of hills of Jammu & Himachal. The Rajput rulers of princely states especially Nurpur, Jammu, Mankot, Guler, Basohli, Chamba, Bandralta, Jasrota, Jaswan were particularly devoted to the Pandori dham. The second Mahant of Pandori dham, Shri Narainji is said to have survived the ordeal inflicted to him by Muslim Emperor Jahangir who had poisoned him to test his miraculous powers. Shri Narainji survived which left Jahangir feel ashamed and ultimately led him to accept the supremacy of the shrine. The shrine of Pandori also received royal patronage during the reign of Maharaja Ranjit Singh who often journeyed the shrine for happiness.

temples.name: Ambika Mata Temple
temples.text: The Ambika Mata Temple is dedicated to Goddess Ambika, a form of Goddess Durga. Located in Jagat, Udaipur district, Rajasthan, it is known as the 'Khajuraho of Mewar' due to its intricate carvings and stunning architecture. The temple is a revered pilgrimage site for devotees of the goddess, who is worshipped as the divine mother and protector.
temples.history: The temple dates back to the 10th century and was built during the reign of the Paramara dynasty. It is an excellent example of early Hindu temple architecture, featuring exquisite carvings depicting various deities, celestial beings, and mythological scenes. The temple survived several historical challenges and remains an important spiritual site in Rajasthan.

temples.name: Baba Mohan Rama Temple, Kali Kholi
temples.text: Baba Mohan Rama Temple, located in Kali Kholi, Rajasthan, is dedicated to the revered saint Baba Mohan Rama, who is considered an incarnation of Lord Shiva. Devotees from across the country visit this temple to seek blessings and spiritual guidance.
temples.history: The temple has a deep-rooted history associated with Baba Mohan Rama, who was believed to possess divine powers and performed miracles. The temple serves as an important spiritual center where devotees offer prayers, perform rituals, and take part in religious gatherings.

temples.name: Birla Mandir, Jaipur
temples.text: The Birla Mandir in Jaipur is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and Goddess Lakshmi. This grand temple, built entirely of white marble, is a significant spiritual and architectural landmark in the city.
temples.history: Constructed in 1988 by the Birla family, this temple is part of the series of Birla temples located across India. It is known for its stunning marble carvings, intricate artwork, and serene ambiance. The temple attracts thousands of devotees and tourists annually.

temples.name: Bohra Ganesh Temple
temples.text: Bohra Ganesh Temple is one of the most famous temples in Udaipur, dedicated to Lord Ganesha. The temple is renowned for its unique tradition of a continuously burning lamp, which is believed to bring prosperity and good luck to devotees.
temples.history: The temple is believed to be over 350 years old and has been a site of devotion for Lord Ganesha's followers. The deity is worshipped by people from all walks of life, seeking blessings for success and the removal of obstacles in their endeavors.

temples.name: Brahma Temple, Pushkar
temples.text: The Brahma Temple in Pushkar is one of the very few temples in the world dedicated to Lord Brahma, the creator in Hindu mythology. It is a highly revered pilgrimage site, especially during the Pushkar Fair.
temples.history: Believed to be over 2,000 years old, the temple is said to have been built by the sage Vishwamitra. According to legend, Lord Brahma performed a yagna (sacrificial ritual) at this location, leading to the establishment of the temple. The temple is an architectural marvel, featuring a red spire and intricate carvings.

temples.name: Shri Charbhuja Temple, Rajsamand District
temples.text: Shri Charbhuja Temple, located in Rajsamand district, is dedicated to Lord Vishnu. The deity is worshipped in the form of Charbhuja (four-armed Vishnu), and the temple is an important pilgrimage site for devotees.
temples.history: The temple was built over 5 centuries ago and is known for its historical and religious significance. It is believed that the idol of Charbhuja Vishnu was hidden during wartime to protect it from invaders. The temple is famous for its grand festivals, particularly Janmashtami, which attracts thousands of devotees.

temples.name: Charbhuja Nath Temple
temples.text: Charbhuja Nath Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, located in the Garhbor village of Rajasthan's Bundi district.
temples.history: The temple is believed to be over 5,000 years old and is associated with the Mahabharata era. It is said that the Pandavas worshipped here during their exile. The temple was later reconstructed by Raja Gang Dev in the 14th century after he received divine guidance in his dream. The idol of Lord Vishnu is in the form of Charbhuja (four-armed), holding a conch, discus, mace, and lotus. The temple is revered for its intricate marble carvings and a massive entrance gate, which stands as a testimony to the Rajput architectural grandeur. The annual fair held during Jal Jhulni Ekadashi attracts thousands of devotees from across India.

temples.name: Eklingji Mahadev Temple
temples.text: Eklingji Mahadev Temple is a prominent temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in the town of Eklingji, near Udaipur, Rajasthan.
temples.history: Built in the 8th century by Bappa Rawal, the temple has been an important religious site for the Mewar rulers, who considered Eklingji as their ruling deity. The temple complex consists of 108 smaller shrines, and its main sanctum houses a four-faced idol of Lord Shiva carved from black marble. The temple has undergone several renovations over the centuries, particularly under the rule of Maharana Kumbha. Eklingji Temple remains one of the most revered Shiva temples in Rajasthan, attracting devotees and tourists alike for its historical and spiritual significance.

temples.name: Govind Dev Ji Temple
temples.text: Govind Dev Ji Temple is one of the most significant Krishna temples in India, located in the City Palace complex of Jaipur, Rajasthan.
temples.history: The temple was built in the 18th century by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II, the founder of Jaipur. It houses an idol of Lord Krishna, which is believed to be the exact replica of the form that appeared before his devotee Bajranabh, the great-grandson of Lord Krishna. The idol was originally installed in Vrindavan before being brought to Jaipur by Raja Sawai Man Singh. The temple follows a strict daily schedule of seven aartis and bhogs, drawing thousands of devotees who come to witness the grand celebrations, particularly during Janmashtami and Holi.

temples.name: Jagdish Temple
temples.text: Jagdish Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, located in the heart of Udaipur, Rajasthan.
temples.history: Built in 1651 by Maharana Jagat Singh I, this Indo-Aryan-style temple is one of Udaipur's architectural marvels. The temple stands on a high terrace and is approached by a flight of marble steps. Its spire, adorned with intricate carvings, is visible from a distance. Inside, the sanctum houses a striking black stone idol of Lord Vishnu in his Jagannath form. The temple is an important center of Vaishnavism and attracts pilgrims and tourists alike.

temples.name: Jeen Mata Temple
temples.text: Jeen Mata Temple is a revered temple dedicated to Goddess Jeen Mata, located in the Sikar district of Rajasthan.
temples.history: Jeen Mata Temple is believed to be over a thousand years old and has deep-rooted significance in Rajasthan's folklore. The temple is situated atop a hill and is known for its magnificent architecture. Jeen Mata is worshipped as an incarnation of Goddess Durga, and devotees from all over the country visit the temple, especially during the bi-annual Navratri festival. The temple complex also has a large water tank, which is considered sacred by devotees.

temples.name: Kaila Devi Temple
temples.text: Kaila Devi Temple is a renowned Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Kaila Devi, located in Karauli district, Rajasthan.
temples.history: Kaila Devi Temple is one of the most famous Shakti Peethas in Rajasthan. The temple is believed to have been established in the 13th century by Maharaja Bhompal. The deity is worshipped as a form of Goddess Mahalakshmi. The temple is constructed in the traditional Rajput architectural style, and its annual fair, held in the Hindu month of Chaitra (March-April), draws lakhs of devotees. It is believed that worshiping at the temple fulfills the wishes of devotees and provides divine protection.

temples.name: Kalika Mata Temple, Chittorgarh Fort
temples.text: Dedicated to Goddess Kalika, this temple is one of the most revered shrines in Rajasthan, located within the historic Chittorgarh Fort.
temples.history: Originally built in the 8th century as a Sun Temple, it was later converted into a temple for Goddess Kalika, an incarnation of Goddess Durga. The temple stands as a symbol of power and faith, attracting thousands of devotees annually.

temples.name: Karni Mata Temple, Deshnoke
temples.text: The famous Karni Mata Temple is known for housing thousands of revered rats, which are considered sacred by devotees.
temples.history: Built in the 15th century by Maharaja Ganga Singh of Bikaner, this temple is dedicated to Karni Mata, believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Durga. Devotees consider the rats, known as 'kabbas', to be manifestations of Karni Mata's devotees who have been reborn.

temples.name: Khatu Shyam Temple, Khatu
temples.text: This temple is dedicated to Lord Krishna in his manifestation as Khatu Shyam, revered particularly in Rajasthan.
temples.history: The temple is believed to house the miraculous idol of Khatu Shyam Ji, which was retrieved from the battlefield of Mahabharata. Built in the 11th century, it has since become one of the most visited temples in Rajasthan, especially during the annual Phalguna Mela.

temples.name: Kyarda Hanumanji Temple, Hindaun City
temples.text: A revered temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman, attracting devotees seeking blessings and protection.
temples.history: The temple has a significant following, with legends stating that Lord Hanuman himself blessed this site. Devotees visit in large numbers, especially on Tuesdays and Saturdays, to offer prayers and seek divine intervention.

temples.name: Khatushyamji
temples.text: Khatushyamji Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Barbarika, the grandson of Bhima, worshiped as Khatushyamji. It is located in the Sikar district of Rajasthan.
temples.history: Khatushyamji is believed to be the reincarnation of Barbarika, the grandson of Bhima. According to the legend, before the Mahabharata war, Barbarika vowed to fight for the weaker side. Lord Krishna, knowing that this could change the course of the war, tested his devotion and later granted him a boon that he would be worshiped as Shyam, a manifestation of Krishna, in the Kali Yuga. The temple houses his sacred head, which was retrieved from the Rupavati River by the villagers following divine instructions. Over centuries, this temple has been a revered pilgrimage site for devotees.

temples.name: Madan Mohan Temple, Karauli
temples.text: The Madan Mohan Temple in Karauli is dedicated to Lord Krishna in his Madan Mohan form and is one of the most revered Vaishnav temples in Rajasthan.
temples.history: This temple is believed to have been built in the 16th century by Maharaja Gopal Singh, a devotee of Lord Krishna. The temple enshrines the original deity of Madan Mohan brought from Vrindavan to protect it from Mughal invasions. The temple follows the Pushti Marg tradition established by Saint Vallabhacharya. The grand architecture, intricate carvings, and divine aura of the temple attract devotees from all over India, especially during Janmashtami and other Krishna-related festivals.

temples.name: Mehandipur Balaji Temple
temples.text: Mehandipur Balaji Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Hanuman, known as Balaji in the region. It is located in Todabhim, Rajasthan.
temples.history: Mehandipur Balaji Temple is one of the most well-known temples in India, particularly for its association with exorcism and spiritual healing. The temple is believed to have divine powers, and devotees from across the country visit seeking relief from evil spirits and negative energies. The rituals performed here are unique, involving offerings of mustard oil and continuous chanting of mantras. It is said that the temple was established centuries ago when a priest had a divine vision of Lord Hanuman appearing in the form of Balaji. Over time, the temple grew in prominence, and today, it is one of the most visited spiritual centers in Rajasthan.

temples.name: Moti Dungari Temple
temples.text: Moti Dungari Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha, situated in Jaipur, Rajasthan.
temples.history: The Moti Dungari Temple is an iconic landmark of Jaipur and is dedicated to Lord Ganesha. Built in the 18th century by Maharaja Madho Singh I, the temple is located on a small hill known as Moti Dungari, meaning 'pearl hill.' The architecture of the temple is inspired by the Nagara style and features intricate carvings and elaborate domes. The idol of Lord Ganesha housed in the temple is believed to be over 500 years old and was brought from Gujarat. The temple is a significant religious site, attracting thousands of devotees, especially on Wednesdays and during the Ganesh Chaturthi festival.

temples.name: Nakkash Ki Devi - Gomti Dham
temples.text: Nakkash Ki Devi - Gomti Dham is a sacred temple dedicated to Goddess Durga, situated in Hindaun City, Rajasthan.
temples.history: The Nakkash Ki Devi Temple is an ancient temple known for its religious significance and spiritual energy. It is believed that the temple was established centuries ago and has been a place of worship for devotees seeking blessings from Goddess Durga. The temple is located near the Gomti Kund, a sacred water reservoir, adding to its spiritual aura. Many religious festivals and fairs are held at the temple, attracting large numbers of pilgrims from different parts of Rajasthan and neighboring states. The temple is also known for its beautiful carvings and serene surroundings.

temples.name: Neemach Mata Temple
temples.text: Neemach Mata Temple is a revered temple dedicated to Goddess Neemach Mata, located in Udaipur, Rajasthan.
temples.history: Neemach Mata Temple is situated on a small hill near Fatehsagar Lake in Udaipur. It is dedicated to Goddess Neemach Mata, who is believed to be the guardian deity of the region. The temple is often referred to as the 'Vaishno Devi of Udaipur' due to the difficult trek leading up to it. The temple provides a panoramic view of Udaipur and is a major spiritual destination for devotees, especially during Navratri. The origins of the temple are not precisely documented, but it has been an important place of worship for centuries, with legends linking it to the royal families of Mewar.

temples.name: Osian Temple
temples.text: Osian Temple, located in the Jodhpur district of Rajasthan, is renowned for its ancient temples dedicated to Hindu deities, primarily Sachiya Mata and Mahavira.
temples.history: Osian, often referred to as the 'Khajuraho of Rajasthan,' was an important trading center and religious hub between the 8th and 12th centuries. The temples, built by the Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty, exhibit exquisite carvings and architectural brilliance. The Sachiya Mata Temple is particularly significant, attracting devotees from across the region. Osian's temples also showcase Jain influences, reflecting the town’s rich multicultural history.

temples.name: Rani Sati Temple
temples.text: The Rani Sati Temple in Jhunjhunu is dedicated to Rani Sati, a revered figure known for her self-sacrifice and devotion.
temples.history: The temple, built in memory of Rani Sati, is a unique site as it lacks an idol and instead features a trident symbolizing the goddess. The temple was established over 400 years ago and is a major pilgrimage site for the Marwari community. The complex includes smaller temples dedicated to Lord Hanuman, Lord Ganesha, and Shiva. The annual fair, held during Bhado Amavasya, attracts thousands of devotees.

temples.name: Salasar Balaji Temple
temples.text: Salasar Balaji Temple, located in Salasar town, is dedicated to Lord Hanuman and is a revered pilgrimage site for devotees.
temples.history: The temple was established in 1754 when a unique idol of Hanuman was found in the village.
