The temple’s architecture features Rajput and Mughal influences, and it is known for its grand celebrations during Hanuman Jayanti and Chaitra Purnima. Devotees believe that praying here fulfills wishes and brings prosperity. Over time, the temple has grown into a major religious center in Rajasthan.

temples.name: Sanwaliaji Temple
temples.text: Sanwaliaji Temple is dedicated to Lord Krishna and is located in the Chittorgarh district of Rajasthan.
temples.history: The Sanwaliaji Temple is one of the most revered temples of Lord Krishna in Rajasthan. The temple is known for its black idol of Krishna, which is believed to be self-manifested. It is said that the idol was discovered in the 18th century when three divine idols were found buried in the Bhadsoda-Bagund region. The temple attracts thousands of devotees, particularly during Janmashtami and other Hindu festivals. It is believed that prayers at Sanwaliaji Temple bring prosperity and fulfillment of desires, making it an important pilgrimage site in Rajasthan.

temples.name: Sitaleshwar Temple
temples.text: Sitaleshwar Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is situated in Rajasthan, known for its ancient Shiva Lingam and spiritual significance.
temples.history: Sitaleshwar Temple is an ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, known for its sacred Shiva Lingam that has been worshipped for centuries. The temple is said to have been built by local rulers and has been an important site for Shaivite traditions. The temple is popular during Mahashivratri when devotees gather to offer prayers and perform rituals. It is also known for its peaceful surroundings, attracting pilgrims and tourists who seek blessings and spiritual solace. The temple is a fine example of Rajasthani temple architecture, featuring intricate carvings and historical inscriptions.

temples.name: Sundha Mata Temple
temples.text: Sundha Mata Temple is a famous temple dedicated to Goddess Chamunda, located atop Sundha Hill in the Jalore district of Rajasthan.
temples.history: The Sundha Mata Temple is a revered Hindu pilgrimage site dedicated to Goddess Chamunda, a powerful form of Goddess Durga. It is situated at an elevation of about 1,220 meters on the Sundha mountain in Jalore district. The temple is over 900 years old and features beautiful architecture made of white marble. The sanctum contains an ancient idol of Chamunda Devi. The temple is associated with numerous legends and is considered a significant Shakti Peetha. Devotees visit the temple throughout the year, especially during Navratri, to seek the goddess's blessings. The temple complex also includes a natural water spring and a scenic view of the Aravalli hills.

temples.name: Tanot Mata Temple
temples.text: Tanot Mata Temple is dedicated to Goddess Tanot, located near the Indo-Pak border in the Jaisalmer district of Rajasthan.
temples.history: Tanot Mata Temple is a historic temple of Goddess Tanot, believed to be an incarnation of Goddess Hinglaj. The temple holds immense religious and historical significance due to its association with the Indo-Pakistan wars of 1965 and 1971. It is said that during the war, several enemy bombs failed to explode near the temple, which devotees attribute to the divine protection of the goddess. The temple is maintained by the Border Security Force (BSF) and has become a major pilgrimage site for both soldiers and civilians. Devotees believe that the goddess protects the region and blesses those who visit her temple. The temple is located in the Thar Desert, adding to its mystical charm and attracting tourists from all over the country.

temples.name: Hanuman Tok
temples.text: Hanuman Tok is a Hindu temple complex which is located in the upper reaches of Gangtok, the capital of the Indian state of Sikkim. The temple is dedicated to lord Hanuman, and maintained by the Indian army. It was established in 1952.
temples.history: when Hanuman was flying with the “Sanjeevani”( mythological life saving herb) mountain to save Rama's brother Lakshmana he rested in the spot where his temple now lies for some time. The mandir is actually managed by The Indian Army. Tok means a temple, so it's a temple of Lord Hanuman.

temples.name: Kirateshwar Mahadev Temple
temples.text: Kirateshwar Mahadev Temple is a Hindu temple, identified to be a Hindu pilgrimage site which is located at Legship, Gyalshing district, India along the banks of River Rangeet, which has many episodes of the Mahabharata attached to it. The temple is also known as Kirateshwar Mahadev Thaan by the Kirati people or simply known as Shiv Mandir.
temples.history: According to Hindu beliefs, pleased with Arjuna's hard penance and devotion, Lord Shiva appeared before him in the very spot where the temple lies as hunter Kirateshwar or Lord of the Kiratas and blessed him with success in the Mahabharat War. Long time ago as the people found miraculously existed a stone manifesting Shiva Ling. The said Shiv Ling is the main effigy of worship. Belief of many that a mere visit with true devotion to this temple fulfills one's wishes particularly a wish for son or daughter and also wishes for peace harmony and good health.

temples.name: Thakurbari Temple
temples.text: Thakurbari Temple is a Hindu temple located in Gangtok, Sikkim, India, in the heart of the town. It is one of the oldest Hindu temples in Sikkim built on land donated by the erstwhile Chogyal of Sikkim in 1935. The temple houses almost all major deities and has emerged as an important center of convergence for the Hindu community of Gangtok.
temples.history: It was established in 1935 as a tiny temple on land granted by the former Chogyal of Sikkim. Following that, between 1945 and 1947, the temple was developed to a significant temple complex. The temple has practically all of the major deities and has developed as an important point of convergence for Gangtok’s Hindu population. The temple complex was expanded in 2011 to incorporate a multipurpose hall and a library.On a huge scale, the temple arranges several festivals and social gatherings. These festivities attract a great number of visitors and tourists from all over the world. Visitors gather here to worship the Lord and to accept his blessings.

temples.name: Agartala Jagannath Mandir
temples.text: Jagannath Temple is a Hindu temple located within the Ujjayanta Palace grounds in Agartala, Tripura, India. Built by the Maharaja of Tripura of the Manikya Dynasty in the 19th century, the Jagannath temple is situated in the Ujjayanta Palace grounds and is dedicated to the Hindu Gods Jagannath, Balabhadra and Subhadra.
temples.history: Built in the 19th century by then Maharaja of Tripura, Maharaja Radha Kishore Manikya, this temple with an octagonal base has four stories. The temple is adorned with bright orange stepped up Shikharas

temples.name: Chaturdasha Temple
temples.text: Chaturdasha Temple is a Hindu temple in Agartala, Tripura, India, and features the Tripuri dome patterned after the roofs of village huts in Tripura. The dome is surmounted by a stupa-like structure which reveals traces of Buddhist influence. This temple was built in honour of fourteen deities, together called the Chaturdasha Devata. Devotees visit the temple for the kharchi festival.
temples.history: The temple is fondly called the Chaudda Devata Mandir. The fourteen deities worshipped at the Chaturdasha temple Tripura are called Burasa, Lampra, Bikhatra, Akhatra, Thumnairok, Sangroma, Bonirok, Twima, Songram, Mwtaikotor, Mailuma, Noksumwtai, Swkalmwtai and Khuluma in Kokborok. These deities are the local forms of Hindu Gods and Goddesses who are Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva, Durga, Lakshmi, Kartikeya, Saraswati, Ganesha, Samudra, Prithvi, Agni, Ganga, Himadri and Kamadeva respectively. These deities and the Gods represented here have completely influenced the people of this state which is called the Country of Fourteen Gods and Goddesses. People from the neighboring states also come here in large numbers every year to pray for peace, happiness and prosperity.

temples.name: Lakshmi Narayan Temple
temples.text: Lakshmi Narayan Temple is a Hindu temple, dedicated to the Hindu divine couple Lakshmi Narayana, is located in the Ujjayanta Palace ground in the city of Agartala, Tripura state, India. It was founded by the King of Tripura, Birendra Kishore Manikya, during his reign from 1909 to 1923.
temples.history: The temple was constructed by the King of Tripura, Birendra Kishore Manikya (r. 1909–1923), a century ago

temples.name: Tripura Sundari Temple
temples.text: Tripura Sundari Temple is a Hindu temple of the Goddess Tripura Sundari, better known locally as Devi Tripureshwari the third mahavidya & main form of Parvati. The temple is situated in the ancient city of Udaipur, about 55 km from Agartala, Tripura and can be reached by train and road from Agartala. It is believed to be one of the holiest Hindu shrines in this part of the country and witnesses the highest number of visitors for a temple in North-East India, after Kamakhya Temple in Assam. The state of Tripura is named after this temple. Popularly known as Matabari, the shrine is set upon a small hillock that resembles the hump of a tortoise (Kurma). This shape called Kurmapṛṣṭhākṛti is considered the holiest possible site for a Shakti temple, hence also bestowing the name of Kurma Pīṭha. The Goddess is served by traditional Brahmin priests.
temples.history: Legend has it that King Dhanya Manikya, who ruled over Tripura in the closing years of the 15th century, had a revelation one night in a dream in which Goddess Tripura Sundari instructed him to initiate her worship on the hilltop near the town of Udaipur, the contemporary capital of the kingdom. The king found out that a temple on the hillock was already dedicated to Lord Vishnu. He was in a dilemma, unable to decide how a temple dedicated to Vishnu could have an idol of Shakti. The following night, the divine vision was repeated. The king understood that Vishnu and Shakti were different forms of the same Supreme Deity (Brahman). Thus, the temple of Tripura Sundari came into being around the year 1501 CE. In the dawn of this century, the temple has crossed 500 years. This legend is recounted as an example of solidarity between two sub-groups of Hinduism: the Vaishnava and the Shakta sects.

temples.name: Unakoti
temples.text: Unakoti famously known as Angkor Wat of the North-East, is a sculptural emblem and ancient Shaivite place that hosts rock carvings, figures and images of gods and goddesses. The bas relief sculptures at Unakoti are on stylistic grounds ascribed to 7th to 9th Century CE, to the period of Pre- Manikya rule. The rock art was patronized by Deva Dynasty of Sri Bhumi in Samatata. The only inscription at Unakoti is on the other Chaturmukhalinga image, consisting of a couple of records in Bengali Characters of the 11th to 12th Century CE, which mentions one SriJayadeva, probably a pilgrim.
temples.history: According to Hindu scriptures, Lord Shiva once spent a night here en route to Kashi. 99,99,999 gods and goddesses followed him. He had asked his followers to wake up before sunrise and make their way towards Kashi. Unfortunately, none awoke, except Lord Shiva himself. Before he set out for Kashi alone, he put a curse on the others, turning them to stone and that is how the site got its name.

temples.name: Alopi Devi Mandir
temples.text: Alopi Devi Mandir, located in Prayagraj, is dedicated to Goddess Alopi, believed to be a form of Shakti.
temples.history: Alopi Devi Mandir is unique among Shakti Peethas, as it does not have an idol but a wooden cradle that devotees worship. It is believed that after Sati's body was cut into pieces by Lord Vishnu's Sudarshan Chakra, her last body part disappeared at this location, hence the name 'Alopi' (meaning disappeared). The temple attracts devotees, especially during Navratri, and is considered one of the most sacred Shakti Peeths in India.

temples.name: Bankey Bihari Temple
temples.text: Bankey Bihari Temple, situated in Vrindavan, is dedicated to Lord Krishna in his enchanting 'Bankey Bihari' form.
temples.history: The Bankey Bihari Temple is one of the most famous temples of Vrindavan, dedicated to Lord Krishna in his playful form. The temple was built by Swami Haridas, a great devotee of Krishna, in the 19th century. It houses an idol that appeared miraculously to him. The temple is known for its unique style of worship, where the deity's eyes are briefly unveiled to prevent devotees from being overwhelmed by divine energy. The temple sees thousands of devotees daily, especially during Janmashtami and Holi.

temples.name: Bharat Mata Mandir
temples.text: Bharat Mata Mandir, located in the Mahatma Gandhi Kashi Vidyapith Campus, Varanasi, is dedicated to Mother India.
temples.history: Unlike traditional temples dedicated to deities, Bharat Mata Mandir in Varanasi is dedicated to the spirit of India. It was inaugurated by Mahatma Gandhi in 1936 and features a unique marble relief map of undivided India. The temple celebrates the unity and diversity of the nation, with no idol but a grand map representing India's rivers, mountains, and landscapes. It is a symbol of patriotism and national pride, attracting visitors from all over the country.

temples.name: Chandrika Devi Temple
temples.text: Chandrika Devi Temple, situated in Lucknow, is dedicated to Goddess Chandrika, an incarnation of Durga.
temples.history: Chandrika Devi Temple is an ancient shrine believed to be over 300 years old. It is said that the temple was established by the legendary Lakshmana, the brother of Lord Rama, during the Treta Yuga. The temple is located on the banks of the Gomti River and is a major pilgrimage site for devotees of Goddess Durga. It is especially crowded during Navratri, when thousands of devotees visit to seek blessings. The temple is surrounded by natural beauty, enhancing its spiritual ambiance.

temples.name: Dwarkadhish Temple
temples.text: Dwarkadhish Temple, located in Mathura, is dedicated to Lord Krishna in his Dwarka ruler form.
temples.history: The Dwarkadhish Temple is one of the grandest temples in Mathura, built in 1814 by Seth Gokul Das Parikh. The temple showcases intricate Rajasthani architecture and features a beautiful idol of Lord Krishna as Dwarkadhish (King of Dwarka). The temple is renowned for its grand celebrations during Janmashtami, Holi, and Radhashtami. Thousands of devotees visit daily to offer prayers and witness the mesmerizing rituals performed here.

temples.name: Gorakhnath Math, Gorakhpur
temples.text: The Gorakhnath Math is a prominent monastery associated with the Nath tradition. It is dedicated to Guru Gorakhnath, an important yogi and spiritual leader. The temple attracts devotees from across India, especially during the Makar Sankranti festival, when a grand fair is organized.
temples.history: The origins of Gorakhnath Math trace back to the Nath Sampradaya, a Hindu monastic movement that emphasizes yoga and spiritual discipline. The temple has played a significant role in the socio-political landscape of the region. Guru Gorakhnath, believed to be an incarnation of Lord Shiva, propagated the teachings of yoga, meditation, and self-discipline. Over the centuries, the Math has been a center of spiritual and cultural growth, with various rulers extending patronage. Today, it remains a major pilgrimage site and a symbol of the Nath tradition.

temples.name: Govardhan Shila
temples.text: Govardhan Shila is a revered rock associated with the Govardhan Hill, which Lord Krishna is believed to have lifted to protect the villagers of Vrindavan. Devotees consider circumambulating the hill (Govardhan Parikrama) as a highly sacred act.
temples.history: Govardhan Shila is an integral part of the Krishna Bhakti tradition. According to Hindu mythology, when Lord Indra, the king of the gods, sent torrential rains to punish the villagers of Vrindavan, Lord Krishna lifted the Govardhan Hill on his little finger to provide them shelter. This event is commemorated during Govardhan Puja, a major festival following Diwali. The shilas (sacred stones) from the hill are worshipped as manifestations of Krishna himself. Over the centuries, the site has been visited by countless saints and devotees, making it a center of Vaishnav devotion.

temples.name: Hajari Mahadev Temple, Etawah
temples.text: The Hazari Mahadev Temple is a significant Shiva temple located in Etawah, Uttar Pradesh. It is known for its spiritual aura and is a popular destination for devotees, especially during Mahashivaratri.
temples.history: The temple has ancient roots, with legends linking it to the Mahabharata era. It is believed that the Pandavas worshipped Lord Shiva here during their exile. Over the centuries, the temple has undergone renovations but has retained its sanctity. The annual Shivaratri festival attracts thousands of devotees from surrounding areas.

temples.name: Hanuman Garhi Temple
temples.text: Hanuman Garhi is one of the most revered temples in Ayodhya, dedicated to Lord Hanuman. The temple is situated atop a hill and requires devotees to climb 76 steps to reach the main shrine.
temples.history: The temple was built in the 10th century by a saint named Abhay Ram Das. It holds immense significance in Hindu mythology, as it is believed that Lord Hanuman lived here while guarding Ayodhya. The temple structure, with its massive fort-like architecture, is a testament to the devotion and historical significance attached to it. Thousands of devotees visit daily, particularly on Tuesdays and Saturdays.

temples.name: JK Temple, Kanpur
temples.text: JK Temple, also known as Juggilal Kamlapat Temple, is a beautiful modern temple located in Kanpur. The temple is dedicated to Lord Radha-Krishna and showcases an architectural blend of ancient and contemporary styles.
temples.history: Built in 1953 by the J.K. Trust, the temple was designed to promote spirituality and devotion among the people of Kanpur. The temple features a unique mix of traditional Nagara-style architecture with modern elements. The serene environment and beautifully maintained premises make it a popular place for devotees and tourists alike.

temples.name: Kashi Vishwanath Temple
temples.text: Dedicated to Lord Shiva, Kashi Vishwanath Temple is one of the most revered Hindu temples in India. It is situated in Varanasi, on the western bank of the Ganges River, and is a major center of Shaivism.
temples.history: The temple's origins date back to ancient times and are mentioned in Hindu scriptures like the Puranas. It has been destroyed and rebuilt several times, with the current structure commissioned by Ahilyabai Holkar in 1780. The temple holds immense spiritual significance, being one of the twelve Jyotirlingas. Devotees believe that a visit to Kashi Vishwanath and a dip in the Ganges lead to moksha (liberation). The temple complex underwent major renovations in recent years, enhancing its accessibility and grandeur.

temples.name: Krishna Balrama Mandir
temples.text: Also known as ISKCON Temple Vrindavan, this temple is dedicated to Lord Krishna and Balarama. It is a major spiritual center for devotees of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.
temples.history: The temple was established in 1975 by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, the founder of ISKCON. Designed in the grand traditional style, it attracts devotees from all over the world. It serves as a hub for Krishna bhakti (devotion) and Vedic education, featuring kirtans, bhajans, and discourses on the Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam. The temple's beauty and spiritual ambiance make it a significant pilgrimage site in Vrindavan.

temples.name: Krishna Janmasthan Temple Complex, Mathura
temples.text: This temple marks the sacred birthplace of Lord Krishna in Mathura. It is one of the holiest sites for Hindus and a major pilgrimage destination.
temples.history: According to Hindu tradition, Lord Krishna was born in a prison cell here over 5000 years ago. The site has witnessed several constructions and destructions throughout history. The present temple complex was rebuilt in the 20th century, preserving its spiritual heritage. The temple complex includes the Garbha Griha (sanctum sanctorum) where Krishna is believed to have been born, along with other shrines and a grand hall for religious gatherings. The temple attracts millions of devotees, especially during Janmashtami celebrations.

temples.name: Kusum Sarovar
temples.text: Kusum Sarovar is a sacred reservoir located in Govardhan, near Mathura, Uttar Pradesh. It is associated with the divine pastimes of Lord Krishna and Radha. The serene waters and beautiful architecture attract pilgrims and tourists alike.
temples.history: Kusum Sarovar is believed to be the place where Radha and the gopis collected flowers for Lord Krishna. The present structure was built by the Jat ruler Raja Suraj Mal in the 18th century, featuring grand cenotaphs dedicated to his family. The spot remains an important pilgrimage site for devotees.

temples.name: Lodheshwar Mahadev Mandir, Barabanki
temples.text: Lodheshwar Mahadev Mandir is an ancient Shiva temple located in Barabanki district of Uttar Pradesh. It is famous for its grand Shivratri celebrations and attracts thousands of devotees annually.
temples.history: This temple is said to be from the Dwapara Yuga and has a deep connection with the Pandavas. It is believed that Bhima installed the Shiva Linga here. The temple has been a center of worship for centuries, drawing devotees seeking blessings from Lord Shiva.

temples.name: Mankameshwar Temple, Agra
temples.text: Mankameshwar Temple is one of the oldest Shiva temples in Agra. It is located near the Agra Fort and holds a special significance among devotees.
temples.history: Legend states that Lord Shiva himself appeared here and granted boons to his devotees. The temple is considered highly powerful, and worshippers believe that their wishes get fulfilled upon praying here. The temple sees a huge influx of devotees, especially during Mahashivaratri.

temples.name: Nidhivan, Vrindavan
temples.text: Nidhivan is a sacred temple and forest area in Vrindavan, believed to be the place where Lord Krishna performs Ras Leela with Radha and the gopis at night.
temples.history: Nidhivan is one of the most mysterious and divine places in Vrindavan. Devotees believe that every night, Lord Krishna and Radha perform the Ras Leela here, and anyone who witnesses it does not survive. The dense forest is filled with unique tulsi trees, and legend says they turn into gopis at night. No one is allowed to stay inside the premises after sunset. Many saints and sages have meditated here to experience the divine presence of Lord Krishna. The temple within Nidhivan is dedicated to Radha-Krishna and remains one of the most revered spots in Vrindavan.

temples.name: Prem Mandir, Vrindavan
temples.text: Prem Mandir is a grand temple dedicated to Radha Krishna and Sita Ram, known for its stunning marble architecture and intricate carvings.
temples.history: Prem Mandir was established by Jagadguru Kripalu Maharaj and inaugurated in 2012. It stands as an architectural marvel with intricate carvings depicting the pastimes of Lord Krishna and Radha. The temple is illuminated beautifully at night, making it a major attraction for pilgrims and tourists. The temple complex also features beautiful gardens and fountains. The main sanctum houses deities of Radha-Krishna on the first floor and Sita-Ram on the second floor, signifying divine love and devotion.

temples.name: Radha Damodar Temple, Vrindavan
temples.text: Radha Damodar Temple is a historic temple dedicated to Radha-Krishna and is deeply associated with the Gaudiya Vaishnav tradition.
temples.history: Radha Damodar Temple was established in 1542 by Srila Jiva Goswami, one of the six Goswamis of Vrindavan. It is considered highly sacred as it houses the original deities worshipped by great saints. The temple also has the samadhi of Srila Rupa Goswami and Bhajan Kutir of Srila Jiva Goswami. The temple is revered as a place of deep spiritual energy, and devotees believe that anyone who visits here attains Krishna's blessings. The courtyard contains the sacred Govardhan Shila, believed to have been touched by Lord Krishna himself.

temples.name: Radha Krishna Vivah Sthali, Bhandirvan
temples.text: Radha Krishna Vivah Sthali is a sacred site located in Bhandirvan, where it is believed that Lord Krishna and Radha were married spiritually. The temple holds immense significance in Vaishnavism and is a revered destination for devotees. Bhandirvan is one of the twelve forests of Braj and is closely associated with Lord Krishna's pastimes.
temples.history: According to Hindu mythology, Radha and Krishna's divine marriage was conducted here under the Banyan tree (Bhandir Vat), with Lord Brahma himself officiating the ceremony. This event is described in various scriptures and holds a special place in the hearts of Krishna devotees. The site attracts thousands of pilgrims, especially during festivals like Radha Ashtami and Janmashtami. The temple showcases beautiful depictions of Radha and Krishna's wedding and is surrounded by serene natural beauty, enhancing its spiritual ambiance.

temples.name: Radha Kund
temples.text: Radha Kund is one of the holiest water bodies in Vrindavan, associated with Radha and Krishna's divine love. It is believed that taking a dip in this sacred pond grants spiritual blessings and fulfills wishes. Devotees consider it the most sacred of all kunds in the Braj region.
temples.history: Radha Kund is said to have emerged when Radha and her companions wanted to purify themselves after Krishna killed the demon Arishta. To fulfill Radha's wish, Krishna struck the ground, and water from various holy rivers filled the pond. Radha, in response, created her own kund with her sakhis, which became known as Radha Kund. Over time, this place became a significant pilgrimage site, visited by devotees, saints, and sadhus. The kund is surrounded by various small temples and is especially crowded during Kartik Purnima, when thousands of devotees take a holy dip.

temples.name: Radha Madan Mohan Temple, Vrindavan
temples.text: The Radha Madan Mohan Temple is one of the oldest temples in Vrindavan, dedicated to Lord Krishna (Madan Mohan) and Radha.
temples.history: The Radha Madan Mohan Temple was originally established by Sanatan Goswami, a disciple of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, in the 16th century. The temple is known for its historic significance in the Gaudiya Vaishnavism tradition. The original deity of Madan Mohan was later moved to Rajasthan during the Mughal invasion to protect it from destruction. Today, the temple continues to be a major pilgrimage site for devotees of Lord Krishna, who come to seek blessings and experience the divine atmosphere of Vrindavan.

temples.name: Radha Raman Temple
temples.text: The Radha Raman Temple in Vrindavan is dedicated to Lord Krishna as Radha Raman, a form of the divine lover.
temples.history: The Radha Raman Temple was established in 1542 by Gopal Bhatta Goswami, a prominent saint of the Gaudiya Vaishnav tradition. The temple is famous for its self-manifested deity of Radha Raman (Krishna), which is believed to have miraculously appeared from a Shaligram Shila (sacred stone). The temple is one of the seven main temples of Vrindavan and is known for its strict adherence to Vaishnava traditions. The temple does not have a separate idol of Radha, but a crown placed next to Radha Raman represents her presence.

temples.name: Radha Rani Temple, Barsana
temples.text: The Radha Rani Temple, also known as Shriji Temple, is dedicated to Radha, the divine consort of Lord Krishna, and is located in Barsana.
temples.history: The Radha Rani Temple in Barsana is one of the most revered temples dedicated to Goddess Radha, who is considered the embodiment of divine love. The temple is situated atop the Bhanugarh hill and is believed to be built around 5000 years ago. However, the present structure was renovated by Raja Veer Singh in the 17th century. The temple is a significant pilgrimage site, especially during the festival of Holi, where the famous ‘Lathmar Holi’ is celebrated. Devotees from across India visit the temple to seek Radha Rani’s blessings for love and devotion.

temples.name: Radha Vallabh Temple, Vrindavan
temples.text: The Radha Vallabh Temple is one of the most prominent temples of Vrindavan, dedicated to the divine love of Radha and Krishna.
temples.history: The Radha Vallabh Temple was established by Hit Harivansh Mahaprabhu, a 16th-century saint and devotee of Radha Krishna. This temple follows a unique tradition where no idol of Radha is present, and instead, a crown is placed next to Lord Krishna to signify her divine presence. The temple is known for its melodious kirtans and devotion-filled atmosphere, attracting Vaishnav devotees from around the world. It is one of the seven main temples of Vrindavan and continues to be an important center of devotion and spirituality.

temples.name: Ram Mandir, Ayodhya
temples.text: The Ram Mandir in Ayodhya is dedicated to Lord Rama and is regarded as one of the most sacred pilgrimage sites for Hindus.
temples.history: The Ram Mandir in Ayodhya marks the birthplace of Lord Rama, one of the most revered deities in Hinduism. The temple has been a subject of historical and religious significance for centuries. The construction of the grand temple was initiated after a Supreme Court verdict in 2019, and it was inaugurated in 2024. The temple is designed in the traditional Nagara style and is expected to be one of the largest Hindu temples in the world. Ayodhya, as the birthplace of Lord Rama, attracts millions of devotees every year who seek blessings at this sacred site.

temples.name: Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple, Varanasi
temples.text: The Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple is dedicated to Lord Hanuman and is one of the most revered temples in Varanasi.
temples.history: The Sankat Mochan Hanuman Temple was established in the 16th century by the renowned Hindu saint Tulsidas, the author of the Ramcharitmanas. It is believed that Tulsidas had a divine vision of Lord Hanuman at this spot. The temple is famous for its association with Hanuman Chalisa and is visited by thousands of devotees every Tuesday and Saturday. The temple holds special significance for those seeking protection from troubles (‘sankat’). Devotees offer laddoos to Hanuman and chant the Hanuman Chalisa for blessings and strength.

temples.name: Swaminarayan Temple, Chhapaiya, Basti
temples.text: The Swaminarayan Temple in Chhapaiya is the birthplace of Bhagwan Swaminarayan, the founder of the Swaminarayan sect.
temples.history: The Swaminarayan Temple in Chhapaiya marks the birthplace of Sahajanand Swami, later known as Bhagwan Swaminarayan, in the late 18th century. The temple is an important pilgrimage site for followers of the Swaminarayan tradition. It is beautifully constructed with intricate carvings and attracts devotees seeking spiritual enlightenment. The temple celebrates major Swaminarayan festivals and serves as a center of devotion and learning.

temples.name: Ved Mata Gaytri Mandir
temples.text: The Ved Mata Gayatri Mandir is dedicated to Goddess Gayatri, the personification of the sacred Vedas.
temples.history: The Ved Mata Gayatri Mandir is a significant temple dedicated to Goddess Gayatri, who symbolizes wisdom and knowledge. The temple serves as a center for Vedic learning and meditation. It attracts devotees who seek spiritual wisdom and divine blessings. The temple is an important pilgrimage site for those who follow the teachings of the Gayatri Mantra.

temples.name: Vindhyachal Temple, Mirzapur
temples.text: The Vindhyachal Temple is dedicated to Goddess Vindhyavasini and is a major Shakti Peetha in Uttar Pradesh.
temples.history: The Vindhyachal Temple is one of the most sacred temples dedicated to Goddess Durga in her Vindhyavasini form. It is considered a powerful Shakti Peetha and attracts thousands of devotees during Navratri. The temple is situated on the banks of the Ganga River and is believed to be where the goddess chose to reside after vanquishing the demon Mahishasura.

temples.name: Waneshwar Mahadev Temple
temples.text: Waneshwar Mahadev Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in Uttar Pradesh. The temple is a significant spiritual site for Shaivites and attracts devotees throughout the year, especially during Mahashivratri.
temples.history: The Waneshwar Mahadev Temple is an ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, known for its deep-rooted history and religious importance. It is believed that the temple dates back to several centuries and has been a center of Shiva worship for generations. Legends say that the Shiva Lingam in the temple is self-manifested (Swayambhu) and holds immense spiritual power. The temple has been a place of pilgrimage for devotees seeking blessings, peace, and fulfillment of desires. The architecture of the temple reflects traditional Hindu temple styles, with intricate carvings and sacred inscriptions. Throughout history, many saints and sages have meditated in this temple, further enhancing its religious significance. Festivals like Mahashivratri, Shravan Maas, and Kartik Purnima witness grand celebrations, where thousands of devotees gather to offer prayers and perform rituals. The temple continues to be a symbol of divine grace and spiritual enlightenment in Uttar Pradesh.
